grants.title: Nectar flower mix
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Arable land, Uplands, Water Quality, Pollinators and Wildlife
grants.packages: Pollinators and Wildlife, Improving Water Quality
grants.summary: This option provides areas of flowering plants to boost essential food sources for beneficial pollinators.

grants.title: Unharvested cereal headland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option will provide an important food source for farmland birds throughout the year; insects in the summer and both grain and seeding arable plants in winter.

grants.title: Cultivated areas for arable plants
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Arable land, Uplands, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.summary: This option will create uncropped, cultivated areas for a wide range of scarce and declining arable plants, provide areas of less densely vegetated ground for insects and other invertebrates, and summer foraging habitats for declining farmland birds.

grants.title: Supplementary winter feeding for farmland birds
grants.label: What is the weight in tonnes?
grants.summary: This option will provide important food resources for farmland birds in late winter and early spring on arable land and mixed farms by supplementing grown winter bird food with spread seed, once the sown resources have been depleted and before natural food resources become available again in late spring.

grants.title: Brassica fodder crop
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option provides foraging sites for seed-eating birds in pastoral areas where broad-leaved plants can persist in the crop and set seed.

grants.title: Harvested low input cereal
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option will deliver an open-structured cereal crop to provide summer foraging sites for declining and localised farmland birds and habitat for brown hare, rare arable plants and pollinator species, such as bees and beneficial insects.

grants.title: Two year sown legume fallow
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Arable land, Uplands, Water quality, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.packages: Pollinators and Wildlife, Improving Water Quality
grants.summary: This option will provide food for farmland wildlife, such as pollen and nectar for pollinators, and invertebrate chick food for farmland birds. It will also offer a rotational reduction of blackgrass.

grants.title: Autumn sown bumblebird mix
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Arable land, Uplands, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.summary: This option will provide important food resources for farmland birds and a range of nectar feeding insects, including butterflies and bumblebees on arable land and mixed farms.

grants.title: Basic overwinter stubble
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option creates a winter food source for seed-eating birds, which feed on spilt grain and the seeds of broad-leaved weeds. It also creates a foraging habitat for brown hare.

grants.title: Beetle banks
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Arable land, Uplands, Water quality, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.packages: Pollinators and Wildlife, Improving Water Quality
grants.summary: This option provides nesting and foraging habitats for insects (including those that feed on crop pests), bumblebees, small mammals and some farmland birds

grants.title: Skylark plots
grants.label: How many plots?
grants.hint: £18 (£9 per plot, minimum 2 plots per hectare (ha))
grants.use: Arable land, Uplands, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.summary: This option provides skylarks with suitable access to nesting habitats in winter cereal crops throughout their breeding season.

grants.title: Nesting plots for lapwing and stone curlew
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Arable land, Uplands, Water quality, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.packages: Pollinators and Wildlife, Improving Water Quality
grants.summary: This option provides nesting sites for lapwing on arable land. The plots can also benefit other declining farmland birds, brown hare and some important arable plants.

grants.title: Enhanced overwinter stubble
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Arable land, Uplands, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.summary: This option provides important winter food sources for seed-eating birds, spring and summer foraging and nesting habitat for other farmland birds and undisturbed habitat for other farmland wildlife including many pollinators.

grants.title: Whole crop cereals
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Arable land, Uplands, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.summary: This option will provide a valuable seed source in grass-dominated areas, from any unripe spilt grain after harvest and from the stubble in winter. It also delivers resource protection benefits when compared to maize.

grants.title: Flower-rich margins and plots
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Arable land, Uplands, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.summary: This option creates flower-rich grass margins or plots that provide important habitat and foraging sites for invertebrates (including wild pollinators) and birds.

grants.title: Winter bird food
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Arable land, Uplands, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.summary: This option provides important food resources for farmland birds, especially in autumn and winter.

grants.title: Access capital items
grants.label: What is the cost?
grants.hint: We pay up to 100% of actual costs
grants.summary: If successful there will be greater public accessibility of the countryside or enhanced educational visits.

grants.title: Countryside educational access visits accreditation
grants.label: How many agreements?
grants.hint: Only one is allowed for this grant
grants.summary: This allows one member from the agreement holding to go to a training course and become accredited at carrying out enhanced educational experiences.

grants.title: Protection of in-field trees on arable land
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be trees protected from agricultural operations and kept as important features in the local landscape. Tree roots will be protected from damage by cultivations with a grass fertiliser free buffer. Undisturbed standing and fallen deadwood will act as an invertebrate habitat.

grants.title: Protection of in-field trees on intensive grassland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be trees protected from agricultural operations and kept as important features in the local landscape. Tree roots will be protected from damage by cultivations and a grass fertiliser free buffer. Undisturbed standing and fallen deadwood will act as an invertebrate habitat.

grants.title: Management of hedgerows
grants.label: How long are the hedgerows?
grants.hint: We pay per 100m for 1 side of a hedge
grants.use: Boundaries, Priority habitats, Uplands, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.summary: This option increases the availability of blossom for invertebrates. By allowing fruit and berries to ripen it creates food for over-wintering birds. This option will also improve the structure and longevity of hedgerows.

grants.title: Management of traditional orchards
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be a well-managed traditional orchard with a range of healthy young and old trees. This includes established grass, tall bushy hedges, scrub and tall herb vegetation abundant with invertebrates, birds and wildflowers.

grants.title: Creation of traditional orchards
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be a well-managed traditional orchard with a range of healthy young and old trees. This includes established grass, tall bushy hedges, scrub and tall herb vegetation abundant with invertebrates, birds and wildflowers.

grants.title: Veteran tree surgery
grants.label: How many veteran trees?
grants.summary:
It reduces the rate of loss of veteran trees by carrying out specialist tree surgery to extend their lifespan.

If successful, veteran trees at risk of collapse will be stabilised, resulting in the continuation of:living trees with standing deadwood
trees forming distinctive features in the landscape
trees providing valuable habitat
areas under tree canopies free from scrub, soil compaction, or anything which threatens the tree’s longevity

grants.title: Supplement for restorative pruning of fruit trees
grants.label: How many trees?
grants.summary: If successful there will be restored mature fruit trees with undisturbed standing and fallen deadwood providing a habitat for a wide range of invertebrates.

grants.title: Stone-faced bank repair
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be a rebuilt length of stone-faced bank.

grants.title: Hedgerow supplement - top binding and staking
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be lengths of hedgerow rejuvenated with new growth to form a continuous hedge.

grants.title: Planting new hedges
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be new lengths of hedgerow planted with locally occurring native species.

grants.title: Stone wall restoration
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be a rebuilt stone wall which will help to control livestock and conserve traditional landscapes.

grants.title: Stone wall supplement - top wiring
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be a rebuilt stone wall with top-wiring which will help to control livestock and conserve traditional landscapes.

grants.title: Stone wall supplement - stone from quarry
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be a rebuilt stone wall on sites where there was insufficient re-usable stone on the farm.

grants.title: Stone wall supplement - difficult sites
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be a rebuilt stone wall which will help to control livestock and conserve traditional landscapes.

grants.title: Stone-faced bank restoration
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be a rebuilt length of stone-faced bank.

grants.title: Earth bank creation
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be a new length of earth bank which will conserve and enhance landscape character and provide a valuable wildlife habitat.

grants.title: Earth bank restoration
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be a length of rebuilt earth bank which will conserve and enhance landscape character and provide a valuable wildlife habitat.

grants.title: Hedgerow laying
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be lengths of hedgerow rejuvenated with new growth to form a continuous hedge.

grants.title: Hedgerow coppicing
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be lengths of hedgerow rejuvenated with new growth to form a continuous hedge

grants.title: Hedgerow gapping-up
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.use: Boundaries, Priority habitats, Uplands, Water quality
grants.packages: Pollinators and Wildlife, Improving Water Quality
grants.summary: If successful there will be lengths of hedgerow with gaps planted up to create a continuous length of hedge.

grants.title: Hedgerow supplement - casting up
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be lengths of hedgerow which have been re-profiled and had slipped soil replaced.

grants.title: Hedgerow supplement - substantial pre-work
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: If successful, lengths of restored hedgerow which required substantial pre-work or were located on difficult sites will be restored.

grants.title: Management of coastal sand dunes and vegetated shingle
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.packages: Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation, Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk, Drought and Wildfire Mitigation
grants.summary: It is designed to make sure that existing coastal sand dunes and vegetated shingle sites are managed appropriately. This includes both sites in good condition or those that need restoration, such as where management has stopped or scrub has invaded.

grants.title: Creation of coastal sand dunes and vegetated shingle on arable land and improved grassland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.packages: Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation, Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk, Drought and Wildfire Mitigation
grants.summary:
It creates sand dunes and coastal vegetated shingle on arable land or improved grassland locations that were:

once part of sand dune or shingle systems
next to active sand dune or shingle systems
If successful, developing features will include:

sand dunes and vegetated shingle
transition areas (transitions between shingle and dune and nearby habitats)
the specialised and local species that sand dunes and vegetated shingle in the area support

grants.title: Management of coastal saltmarsh
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.packages: Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation, Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk, Drought and Wildfire Mitigation
grants.summary:
It maintains coastal saltmarsh in good condition and restores saltmarsh in unfavourable condition when grazing or cutting are key factors.

If successful there will be:

saltmarsh areas in favourable condition on Sites of Special Scientific Interest (SSSIs), meaning they are adequately conserved and are meeting conservation objectives
saltmarsh areas in improving condition if not on SSSIs, meaning measures are in place that if maintained will make them favourable over time
a mosaic of open habitats and bare ground with typical saltmarsh plant species such as sea aster, sea purslane, sea-blite and sea-lavender, although the exact species will depend on the location of the saltmarsh
a gradual change from less stable and seasonal habitats on the seaward side to the more stable, well-established landward saltmarsh and transitions covered only by the highest tides

grants.title: Creation of inter-tidal and saline habitat on arable land
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It creates inter-tidal and saline habitats, including transitional areas (transitions between saltmarsh and nearby habitats), on arable land or improved grassland.

grants.title: Creation of inter-tidal and saline habitat by non-intervention
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.packages: Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation, Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk, Drought and Wildfire Mitigation
grants.summary: It creates inter-tidal and saline habitats, including transitional areas (transitions between saltmarsh and nearby habitats), following the unmanaged breach of sea walls or the overtopping of sea walls

grants.title: Coastal vegetation management supplement
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It supports saltmarsh vegetation management, for example by reducing existing levels of grazing, or introducing grazing or cutting.

grants.title: Creation of inter-tidal and saline habitat on intensive grassland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.packages: Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation, Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk, Drought and Wildfire Mitigation
grants.summary: It creates inter-tidal and saline habitats, including transitional areas (transitions between saltmarsh and nearby habitats), on grassland or improved grassland.

grants.title: Educational Access
grants.label: How many visits?
grants.summary: This options lets school pupils visit the farm for educational experiences and allows for care farming visits.

grants.title: Fencing
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.use: Grassland, Livestock management, Priority habitats, Uplands, Water quality, Woodland
grants.packages: Improving Water Quality, Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation
grants.summary: If successful this item will help control livestock and protect environmental features. It will also help to manage habitats.

grants.title: Temporary deer fencing
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: It will protect newly coppiced woodland from deer browsing as part of a wider woodland management project.

grants.title: Deer exclosure plot
grants.label: How many plots?
grants.summary: It will protect areas of woodland that are approximately 16 square metres in size from deer browsing. This will allow monitoring of the area’s regeneration potential and the impact of browsing.

grants.title: Wooden field gate
grants.label: How many gates?
grants.use: Grassland, Livestock management, Priority habitats, Uplands, Woodland
grants.summary: This item helps stock management, or will stop livestock from getting into an area where they may cause damage, such as a historic or archaeological feature. This will stockproof ditch crossing points by linking the gate to the ditch edge.

grants.title: Stone gate post
grants.label: How many posts?
grants.summary: It will help conserve local landscape character and sites of historic interest by establishing stone gate posts made from local materials in local styles.

grants.title: Badger gate
grants.label: How many gates?
grants.summary: This item allows badgers to pass freely through the fence to reduce the damage they cause to fence lines (which were themselves installed to benefit habitats through appropriate grazing).

grants.title: Water gates
grants.label: How many gates?
grants.use: Livestock management, Uplands, Water quality, Woodland
grants.summary: This item will prevent livestock from entering watercourse channels. It will also stop livestock from trampling waterside banks and will leave bankside vegetation lush and unbroken by livestock paths.

grants.title: Sheep netting
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.use: Grassland, Livestock management, Priority habitats, Uplands, Water quality, Woodland
grants.packages: Improving Water Quality, Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation
grants.summary: If successful there this item will protect environmental features from livestock. It will also help manage habitats.

grants.title: Permanent electric fencing
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.use: Grassland, Livestock management, Priority habitats, Uplands, Water quality
grants.summary: If successful this item will help control livestock and protect environmental features. It will also help to manage habitats.

grants.title: Rabbit fencing supplement
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.use: Grassland, Livestock management, Priority habitats, Uplands, Water quality, Woodland
grants.summary: This item helps control rabbits, protects environmental features and helps to manage habitats.

grants.title: Fencing supplement - difficult sites
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.use: Grassland, Livestock management, Priority habitats, Uplands, Woodland
grants.summary: This supplement helps control livestock, protects environmental features and helps to manage habitats on difficult sites.

grants.title: Anti-predator combination fencing
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: It increases the productivity of priority ground-nesting birds when used with effective habitat management.

grants.title: Anti-predator temporary electric fencing
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: It increases the productivity of priority ground-nesting birds when used with effective habitat management.

grants.title: Deer fencing
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.summary: It will protect newly created or existing woodland from deer browsing as part of a wider woodland creation or woodland management project.

grants.title: Management of geodiversity features
grants.label: What is the actual cost?
grants.hint: We will pay up to 100% of actual costs
grants.summary: If successful this item will ensure sensitive geological features are managed positively and protected from damage.

grants.title: Major preparatory works for priority habitats (creation and restoration) and priority species
grants.label: What is the actual cost?
grants.hint: We will pay up to 100% of actual costs
grants.summary: If successful this item will result in large scale restoration and creation of priority habitats and bespoke management for priority species.

grants.title: Deer high seat
grants.label: How many units?
grants.summary: It will provide a safe, temporary vantage point from which to cull deer, reducing the impact their browsing has on the land.

grants.title: Woodland infrastructure
grants.label: What is the actual cost?
grants.hint: We will pay up to 40% of actual costs
grants.summary: It makes woodlands more accessible by road, allowing timber and other forest products to be moved more easily. This improves the management of the woodland. Applications for a Woodland Creation Grant can include this item to support the establishment of new woodland through the movement of planting stock (forestry products) and their maintenance, where the woodland creation plan in your application identifies that poor access currently prevents this.

grants.title: Take small areas out of management
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Grassland, Uplands, Water quality, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.packages: Pollinators and Wildlife, Improving Water Quality
grants.summary: This option creates a year-round habitat and food for a range of wildlife. If successful there will be tall grass tussocks with abundant flowering plants during the summer and dead seed heads throughout the winter.

grants.title: Management of grassland for wintering waders and wildfowl
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It will provide habitat in wet grassland for wintering wildfowl and wading birds. Fields will have wet areas throughout the winter, attracting wading birds and wildfowl, which will be able to feed and roost undisturbed.

grants.title: Creation of wet grassland for breeding waders
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It will create wet grassland for breeding wading birds from arable or temporary grassland. Fields will have well-established swards, with wet areas throughout the winter and spring and into the early summer. Waders will be able to nest and, in most years, successfully fledge their young.

grants.title: Creation of wet grassland for wintering waders and wildfowl
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It will create wet grassland for wintering wildfowl and wading birds from arable or temporary grassland. Fields will have well-established swards, with wet areas throughout the winter. Wading birds and wildfowl will be able to feed and roost undisturbed.

grants.title: Management of grassland for target features
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It will maintain or increase the quantity of the targeted habitat, species or features. Many priority species such as bumblebees, butterflies, birds or bats will also benefit. Buried archaeological features will not be disturbed.

grants.title: Creation of grassland for target features
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It will establish a suitable sward with a range of grass, legume and wildflower species. This will protect and enhance the targeted feature, as well as benefiting a range of other species, such as bumblebees, butterflies, birds or bats. Buried archaeological features will not be disturbed.

grants.title: Hay making supplement
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This supplement allows a crop of herb-rich hay to be grown and harvested, which will lead to wildflowers and grasses blossoming and setting seed. This will help to conserve many of the plants in the meadow and provide pollen and nectar for bees and other insects.

grants.title: Rush infestation control supplement
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This supplement is a short-term incentive to reduce rush cover in parcels with heavy infestations. It will help prevent the loss of botanically rich grasslands or provide nesting areas for breeding wading birds. The rush cover on the site will reduce to below 30%.

grants.title: Lenient grazing supplement
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This supplement provides the critical spring and summer invertebrate food needed by species such as yellowhammers.

grants.title: Permanent grassland with very low inputs (outside SDAs)
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Grassland, Water quality, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.packages: Pollinators and Wildlife, Improving Water Quality, Air Quality
grants.summary: If successful there will be more flowering grass and wildflower species, varied structures offering nectar and shelter for invertebrates and increased food supply for birds

grants.title: Ryegrass seed-set as winter food for birds
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option will lead to an abundance of ryegrass seed in the autumn, providing food for many birds (including yellowhammers and other buntings, gamebirds such as grey partridge, and skylarks) until late winter.

grants.title: Legume and herb-rich swards
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.packages: Pollinators and Wildlife, Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation
grants.summary: This option will produce a vigorous sward with abundant legumes and herbs suitable for productive cattle and sheep. It will also provide habitat and food for invertebrates, including crop pollinators, and improve soil structure and water infiltration.  This option doesnâ€™t use nitrogen fertilisers, which contribute to climate change.

grants.title: Permanent grassland with very low inputs in SDAs
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: If successful there will be more flowering grass and wildflower species, varied structures offering nectar and shelter for invertebrates and increased numbers of ground-nesting and feeding birds (particularly waders such as lapwing and snipe)

grants.title: Management of species rich grassland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It will maintain and enhance priority grasslands. It will increase the number and frequency of important plant species, with most wildflowers in bloom over the summer. Many other priority species, such as bumblebees, butterflies, birds or bats, will benefit, and buried archaeological features will not be disturbed.

grants.title: Restoration towards species-rich grassland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It will restore grasslands that have the potential to become priority grasslands. It will increase the number and frequency of important plant species. Many other priority species, such as bumblebees, butterflies, birds or bats, will also benefit. Buried archaeological features will not be disturbed.

grants.title: Creation of species-rich grassland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It will create priority grasslands and establish a wide range of important plant species. Many other priority species, such as bumblebees, butterflies, birds or bats, will also benefit, and buried archaeological features will not be disturbed.

grants.title: Management of grassland for breeding waders
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It will provide habitat in wet grassland for breeding wading birds. Fields will have wet areas and suitable sward conditions throughout the winter and spring and into the early summer. Waders will be able to nest and, in most years, successfully fledge their young.

grants.title: Historic and archaeological feature protection
grants.label: What is the actual cost?
grants.hint: We will pay up to 100% of actual costs
grants.packages: Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation, Heritage, Access and Engagement
grants.summary: It is for physical works that directly relate to conserving or protecting historic environment features in the landscape. This will help the long-term survival of historic and archaeological features.

grants.title: Historic building restoration
grants.label: What is the actual cost?
grants.hint: We will pay up to 80% of actual costs
grants.summary: It is for conserving and lengthening the life of rural buildings that contribute to the character and enjoyment of the landscape and are of historic interest. The work will prevent further decay to the fabric of historic buildings and benefit their long-term survival.

grants.title: Removal of eyesore
grants.label: How many items?
grants.packages: Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk, Heritage
grants.summary: It removes and disposes of unsightly items which have a negative effect on the landscape.

grants.title: Maintenance of weatherproof traditional farm buildings
grants.label: What's the size in square meters?
grants.summary: This option will help to maintain traditional farm buildings, using traditional methods and materials. This will also enhance the local landscape and preserve places for wildlife.

grants.title: Take historic and archaeological features out of cultivation
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Arable land, Historic environment, Uplands, Water quality
grants.summary: This option will protect historic and archaeological features from damaging cultivation practices. Depending on land use and location this option may also reduce diffuse pollution and reduce soil erosion

grants.title: Reduced-depth, non-inversion cultivation on historic and archaeological features
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option will reduce damage to historic and archaeological features under cultivation by using non-inversion (minimum tillage) machinery and shallower cultivation depths.

grants.title: Scrub control on historic and archaeological features
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option will reduce the risk of root damage to historic and archaeological features by permanently removing the majority of scrub from them.

grants.title: Management of historic and archaeological features on grassland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Educational access, Grassland, Historic environment, Uplands
grants.summary: This option will maintain permanent grassland on historic and archaeological features. By maintaining these features the character of the farm will be conserved and Englandâ€™s heritage protected for future generations.

grants.title: Maintenance of designed/engineered water bodies
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Educational access, Grassland, Historic environment, Uplands
grants.packages: Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation, Heritage, Access and Engagement
grants.summary: This option protects the banks and associated historic built water-control features of designed or engineered historic water bodies. It maintains or strengthens the role of these features in water quality management.

grants.title: Management of historic water meadows through traditional irrigation
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Educational access, Grassland, Historic environment, Uplands
grants.summary:
It protects heritage by conserving historic water meadow systems and keeping them in a stable condition.

It maintains the demanding traditional management needed on both ‘bedwork’ and ‘catch’ water meadows. It also maintains habitat and water quality.

grants.title: Maintenance of weatherproof traditional farm buildings in remote areas
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option will help to maintain traditional farm buildings, using traditional methods and materials. This will also enhance the local landscape and preserve places for wildlife.

grants.title: Restricted depth crop establishment to protect archaeology under an arable rotation
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option reduces the risk of damage to historic and archaeological features on arable land, particularly where subtle earthwork remains survive.

grants.title: Management of lowland heathland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary:
It creates a diverse mosaic of vegetation, allowing all heathland types (such as wet or dry heath, transitional heaths, acidic mires and coastal heaths) to flourish. This includes pioneer heath and bare ground, which benefits rarer invertebrates, birds, reptiles and plants.

If successful there will be heathland areas with a diverse mosaic structure, including undisturbed bare ground and vegetation in all stages of its life cycle.

The cover of undesirable species will be low and species that increase when undermanaged (bracken, trees, dense grass tussocks) kept under control. Locally characteristic plant communities and the species they support (such as nightjar, woodlark, smooth snake and sand lizard, where within their range) are common.

grants.title: Restoration of forestry and woodland to lowland heathland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary:
It re-establishes lowland heathland on forested land or land recently (since 1900) colonised by woodland.

Once trees are felled and removed and extensive areas of sandy soil are exposed, heathland areas should develop over the first 2 to 3 years. The area will have a tree cover under 15%, with a diverse mosaic structure and composition, including undisturbed bare ground and varied heathland vegetation types.

The cover of undesirable species will be low and vegetation that increases when undermanaged (bracken, scrub, dense grass tussocks) should be kept under control.

Locally characteristic plant communities and the species they support (such as nightjar, woodlark, smooth snake or sand lizard) will successfully colonise the site, if within their range.

grants.title: Creation of heathland from arable or improved grassland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary:
Lowland heathland will be created, which includes mosaics with lowland acid grassland, on arable or improved grassland sites that have largely lost their heathland seed bank.

Heathland species should normally start to appear within 1 to 3 years. The heathland areas in this option will develop a diverse mosaic structure and composition, including undisturbed bare ground and varied vegetation of different ages.

The cover of undesirable species should be low and vegetation that increases when undermanaged (such as bracken, trees, dense grass tussocks) will need to be kept under control. Locally characteristic plant communities and the species they support (such as nightjar, woodlark, smooth snake or sand lizard) will colonise the site, if it’s within their range.

grants.title: Cattle grid
grants.summary: It creates environmental benefits by aiding grazing management. Benefits include better management of priority habitats or landscape enhancement.

grants.summary:
It controls the spread of, or removes, existing dense stands of bracken. This will maintain or restore biodiversity value and protect archaeological sites.

If successful the underlying vegetation will develop and spread, and will develop a diverse mosaic structure and composition, including undisturbed bare ground and varied vegetation types.

Successfully managing the remaining vegetation (usually by grazing or cutting) will reduce the chances of bracken spreading back. Locally characteristic plant communities and the species they support will expand or even colonise the site.

Japanese knotweed
floating pennywort and other invasive aquatic plants

overgrazing reduced in some areas and increased in others
better habitats for birds, mammals and insects
less damage to archaeological features and vulnerable soils and less poaching (trampling)
more suitable conditions for threatened species to thrive
improved visibility of historic and archaeological features

grants.summary: This option will remove livestock at particular times of the year from fields adjacent to a watercourse that are prone to waterlogging, compaction or poaching. grants.title: Riparian management strip
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?

grants.packages: Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation, Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk, Drought and Wildfire Mitigation

If successful there will be:

new areas of river and wetland habitats appearing, such as new channels, temporary ponds in old channels and wet grassland
gradual erosion and movement of the river bed and river banks
deposits of gravel, sand and silt appearing in the river channel and on the floodplain after a flood

grants.title: Very low nitrogen inputs to groundwaters
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It will reduce nutrient input to grassland in highly targeted locations to help slow or reverse nutrient levels in groundwater. This will be targeted to help specific designated sites and Water Framework Directive Protected Areas.

grants.title: Nil fertiliser supplement
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This supplement with help to reduce the risk of nitrate loss to ground and surface water by reducing nutrient inputs to zero.

grants.title: Flood mitigation on arable reversion to grassland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Arable land, Flood risk, Grassland, Water quality
grants.packages: Improving Water Quality, Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk
grants.summary:
It will intercept and slow surface runoff from rainfall events and provide space for water from streams and rivers to be stored during a flood event to help manage flood risk. It can be used in three ways:

to slow down surface runoff on land outside the floodplain by creating temporary storage behind suitable structures such as low earth bunds and modified field-boundaries, or enhanced hollows and depressions
to enable the re-connection of the river with the floodplain in areas that will not attract funding from an Environment Agency (EA) flood scheme or option SW12 - Making space for water. Flood water will be allowed to spread across the land and naturally subside
to reconnect the river and floodplain in association with specific Priority River Habitats and SSSIs where the Making Space for Water option is targeted
If successful there will be new areas of temporary water storage both in the floodplain and outside it that help delay peak flood flows reaching communities and infrastructure at risk of flooding.

grants.title: Flood mitigation on permanent grassland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.packages: Improving Water Quality, Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk
grants.summary:
It will intercept and slow surface runoff from rainfall events and provide space for water from streams and rivers to be stored during a flood event to help manage flood risk. It can be used in three ways:

to slow down surface runoff on land outside the floodplain by creating temporary storage behind suitable structures such as low earth bunds and modified field-boundaries, or enhanced hollows and depressions
to enable the re-connection of the river with the floodplain in areas that will not attract funding from an Environment Agency (EA) flood scheme or option SW12: Making space for water. Flood water will be allowed to spread across the land and naturally subside
to reconnect the river and floodplain in association with specific Priority River Habitats and SSSIs where the Making Space for Water option is targeted
If successful there will be new areas of temporary water storage both in the floodplain and outside it that help delay peak flood flows reaching communities and infrastructure at risk of flooding.

grants.title: 4m to 6m buffer strip on intensive grassland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option will provide new habitat, and protect existing landscape features.

grants.title: In-field grass strips
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option will establish permanent grass areas or strips. This will help reduce the quantity of sediment, nutrients and pesticides transported through surface runoff water, both within fields and from field to field.

grants.title: 12m to 24m watercourse buffer strip on cultivated land
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option will establish a permanent grass buffer. This will help reduce the risk of potential pollutants, such as sediment, pesticides and nutrients (mainly phosphate), being transported to watercourses in surface water runoff. It may also provide habitat for wildlife, and form links between other habitats.

grants.title: Enhanced management of maize crops
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option will reduce the risk of soil erosion and surface runoff in fields where maize is grown. It will slow runoff water before it builds to a damaging flow, and remove sediment, organic material, nutrients and chemicals carried in the water.

grants.title: Winter cover crops
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option will establish cover crops to reduce nitrate leaching on land that would normally be left bare or down to stubbles during winter. It may also reduce the risk of potential pollutants, such as sediment and nutrients, being carried to neighbouring watercourses.

grants.title: Arable reversion to grassland with low fertiliser input
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option will establish a dense grass sward in arable fields that are at risk of soil erosion or surface runoff. This will stabilise the soil, reduce nutrient losses, and buffer sensitive habitats such as, designated aquatic habitats. It will also reduce surface runoff, which may help to reduce the risk of flooding.

grants.title: Management of intensive grassland adjacent to a watercourse
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option will reduce stocking density and fertiliser inputs on improved grassland.  This will help reduce soil compaction, surface run-off and risk of diffuse pollution to the watercourse. Reducing surface runoff may help to reduce the risk of flooding. The option may also reduce the risk of nitrate loss to ground and surface water if it is used with SW14 - Nil fertiliser supplement.

grants.title: Seasonal livestock removal on intensive grassland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option will remove livestock at particular times of the year from fields adjacent to a watercourse that are prone to waterlogging, compaction or poaching. This will help improve soil structure, reduce surface runoff and risk of diffuse pollution to the watercourse. Reducing surface runoff may help to reduce the risk of flooding.

grants.title: Planting standard hedgerow tree
grants.label: How many trees?
grants.summary: If successful there will be a newly planted standard hedgerow tree.

grants.title: Coppicing bankside trees
grants.label: How many trees?
grants.summary: Bankside habitat will benefit by restorative coppicing of overgrown trees, either by coppicing to ground level and allowing the cut stool to regrow or by singling of an overgrown coppice stool where a single stem is selected and allowed to grow on to a mature tree.

grants.title: Tree surgery
grants.label: How many trees?
grants.summary: Use this item to maintain and enhance the character of the landscape by managing and/or restoring mature trees, to prolong their lives, and maintain their wildlife and/or historic value.

grants.title: Stump grinding
grants.label: How many stumps?
grants.use: Priority habitats, Trees (non-woodland), Uplands, Vegetation control
grants.summary:
It is used to support habitat restoration and management by removing tree stumps that would otherwise restrict access for restoration or management works.

If successful stumps will have been cleared, there will be little or no ground disturbance and wood chippings will have been removed.

grants.title: Creation of dead wood habitat on trees
grants.label: How many trees?
grants.summary:
It promotes continuity in the provision of dead wood habitat to benefit rare or specialised wildlife where there is a generational gap between existing veteran trees and their successors.

If successful there will be deliberate ‘damage’ or ageing of younger trees in association with veteran trees where there is a generation gap in the recruitment of future veterans. This will mimic the natural damage caused for example by lightning strikes, branch failure and woodpecker holes, speeding up of the process of producing valuable wood decay habitats otherwise only found in very old trees.

grants.title: Identification of orchard fruit tree varieties
grants.label: How many fruit tree varieties?
grants.summary: If successful local and rare varieties of fruit trees will be identified which will help select varieties to be planted in orchard restoration projects.

grants.title: Planting standard parkland tree
grants.label: How many trees?
grants.summary: If successful new standard trees will be established in wood pasture and parklands, replacing lost trees or restoring sustainable populations.

grants.title: Planting fruit trees
grants.label: How many trees?
grants.summary: If successful new fruit trees will be established in traditional orchards and hedgerows.

grants.title: Supply and plant tree
grants.label: How many trees?
grants.packages: Air Quality, Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation
grants.summary: It will help create a range of environmental and social benefits; supports wildlife, particularly when new woodland links habitats or creates a protective buffer; reduces the risk of floods, improve water quality and prevents soil erosion; is resilient and can adapt to climate change; enhances the landscape.

grants.title: Supplement for use of individual tree-shelters
grants.label: How many tree shelters?
grants.summary: It provides tree shelters to protect young, establishing trees from damage by browsing animals.

grants.title: Tree guard (tube and mesh)
grants.label: How many guards?
grants.summary: If successful this item will protect trees from damage caused by grazing animals and wild animals.

grants.title: Tree guard (wood post and rail)
grants.label: How many guards?
grants.summary: If successful this item will protect trees from damage caused by grazing animals and wild animals.

grants.title: Tree guard (wood post and wire)
grants.label: How many guards?
grants.summary: If successful this item will protect trees from damage caused by grazing animals and wild animals.

grants.title: Parkland tree guard - welded steel
grants.label: How many trees?
grants.summary:
Use metal tree guards to protect standard trees from vandalism, mowing, livestock and wild animals in parkland and areas with public access.

Use guards traditional to the area.

This item cannot be used to replace existing guards to maintain the parkland’s character.

grants.title: Enclosed rough grazing
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option maintains and enhances areas of enclosed rough grazing land within an upland farming system. This land contains extensive areas of moorland vegetation but it does not meet moorland priority habitat status over the majority of the parcel.

grants.title: Management of rough grazing for birds
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option is for restoring or maintaining upland bird populations. These are normally breeding waders such as lapwing, snipe, redshank, curlew and golden plover, but may also include yellow wagtail, black grouse or other priority species.

grants.title: Management of moorland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary:
It will:

maintain and restore moorland priority habitats and ecosystem function
maintain and restore species
protect historic features
strengthen landscape character
If successful there will be:

improved condition of moorland habitats and associated species
enhanced soil management
reduced diffuse pollution
improvements to water quality and flood risk management
historic environmental features with no bare soil or poaching (trampling)
stabilized and permanently re-vegetated areas that were previously eroded
historic features unaffected by trees, bracken and scrub
no animal burrows developing on historic features

grants.title: Management of moorland vegetation supplement
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary:
It is for carrying out an appropriate programme of vegetation management to contribute to restoration and improvement in functionality of priority habitats such as dry heath, wet heath and blanket bog where significant changes to current management are required.

If successful there will be a significant change to burning and/or cutting management so that it is carried out to promote restoration of habitats. These changes will have created more diverse vegetation or opportunities for colonisation by key species such as Sphagnum. There will also be positive impacts on water quality, reduced erosion and enhanced carbon storage.

grants.title: Moorland re-wetting supplement
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary:
It will maintain and restore vegetation mosaics, wetland habitats and associated wildlife.

If successful there will be:

improved hydrology of moorland habitats
benefits to upland flora and fauna, eg increased sphagnum moss growth
benefits to historic features
strengthened landscape character
improved breeding habitat for invertebrates, a food source for grouse and wader chicks

grants.title: Upland livestock exclusion supplement
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary:
It will improve habitat and feature conditions.

If successful there will be:

increased rates of heather regeneration
improved rates of flowering of rare species such as spring gentian
a regeneration of scrub such as juniper
improved downstream water quality
improvements in the condition and visibility of archaeological sites and other historic features

grants.title: Small wildlife box
grants.label: How many boxes?
grants.summary: This item provides artificial nesting, roosting and hibernation sites for specific mammals, birds and invertebrates.

grants.title: Medium wildlife box
grants.label: How many boxes?
grants.summary: This item provides artificial nesting, roosting and hibernation sites for specific mammals and birds. This includes tree sparrow and targeted bat species.

grants.title: Large wildlife box
grants.label: How many boxes?
grants.summary: This item provides artificial nesting and roosting sites for large birds, in particular barn owls and kestrels.

grants.title: Woodland creation - maintenance payments
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.packages: Improving Water Quality, Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation
grants.summary:
It will help create woodland that:

supports wildlife, by linking habitats together or providing a protective buffer between them
reduces the risk of floods, improves water quality and prevents soil erosion
is resilient and can adapt to climate change
enhances the landscape

grants.title: Woodland improvement
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It will improve the biodiversity of woodland and/or make it more resilient to climate change.

grants.title: Woodland edges on arable land
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option allows a scrub and grass mosaic to develop on the strip of land adjacent to woodland. If successful a scrub and grass mosaic will have developed through natural regeneration between the arable land and existing woodland. New woodland edge habitat will have been created resulting in an increase in birds, invertebrates, small mammals and other wildlife.

grants.title: Management of wood pasture and parkland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Historic environment, Priority habitats, Uplands, Woodland
grants.packages: Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation, Heritage
grants.summary: This option will maintain existing lowland wood pasture and parkland on sites that still support mature and veteran trees.

grants.title: Restoration of wood pasture and parkland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Historic environment, Priority habitats, Uplands, Woodland
grants.packages: Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation, Heritage
grants.summary:
It restores existing lowland wood pasture and parkland on sites that support veteran trees or parkland features.

If successful there will be many of the following, depending on whether the site is predominantly wood pasture, parkland or a combination of both:

undisturbed standing and fallen deadwood that will provide habitats for invertebrates
additional semi-mature or mature trees that will provide continuity of the tree population
newly planted trees, spaced evenly with open crowns or patches of regeneration with space to allow open grown crowns to develop
open grown scrub covering 10% to 20% of the wood pasture
flowering trees and scrub such as hawthorn, crab apple and wild pear to provide food and nectar sources for invertebrates
well managed unimproved or semi-improved grassland or heathland, grazed by traditional breed cattle in wood-pasture and deer and traditional breed cattle in parkland
well-maintained historic and archaeological features
well-maintained historic designed landscape planting and features

grants.title: Creation of wood pasture
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary:
It will create new wood-pastures.

If successful there will be:

undisturbed standing and fallen deadwood providing habitats for invertebrates on land adjacent to that where the creation is being carried out
newly planted trees, spaced evenly with open crowns or patches of regeneration with space to allow open grown crowns to develop
open grown scrub covering 10% to 20% of the wood pasture
flowering trees and scrub such as hawthorn, crab apple and wild pear that will provide food and nectar sources for wildlife
enhanced grassland sward or heathland

grants.title: Management of successional areas and scrub
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This option enhances habitats for a wide range of wildlife and improves the quality of the woodland edge. It also helps prevent soil erosion and holds back water to reduce downstream flood risks.

grants.title: Creation of successional areas and scrub
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.packages: Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk, Drought and Wildfire Mitigation
grants.summary:
It regenerates a succession of scrub. This enhances habitats for specific target species and improves the quality of the woodland edge.

Establishing scrub growth also restricts soil erosion and holds back water to reduce downstream flood risks.

If successful there will be:

more scrub growing close to grassland, woodland and other habitats
birds and invertebrates using the scrub
less soil erosion in scrub areas
reduced flooding in scrub areas

grants.title: Livestock exclusion supplement - scrub and successional areas
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: This supplement will help scrub to develop through natural regeneration.

grants.title: Grip blocking drainage channels
grants.label: How many blocks?
grants.use: Flood risk, Priority habitats, Uplands, Water quality
grants.packages: Improving Water Quality, Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk
grants.summary: It will maintain and restore moorland habitats, vegetation mosaics and associated wildlife. If successful there will be restored, re-wetted moorland and peatland habitats supporting target vegetation and species.

grants.title: Construction of water penning structures
grants.label: What is the actual cost?
grants.hint: We will pay up to 100% of actual costs
grants.summary: It will provide bespoke water penning or control structures to support raised water levels for restoring or creating habitats.

grants.title: Creation of scrapes and gutters
grants.label: What's the size in square meters?
grants.use: Flood risk, Grassland, Priority habitats, Uplands
grants.summary: Scrapes provide areas of bare ground, which may be designed to hold water in wet habitats or provide early successional areas in dry habitats. Gutters provide shallow channels to hold/transport water through wet habitats and provide feeding areas for waders.

grants.title: Ditch, dyke and rhine restoration
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.use: Flood risk, Grassland, Priority habitats, Uplands
grants.summary: It restores the wildlife value of overgrown or neglected ditches and helps to establish raised water levels for restoring or creating habitats.

grants.title: Ditch, dyke and rhine creation
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.use: Flood risk, Grassland, Priority habitats, Uplands
grants.summary: It aims to establish raised water levels to help restore or create habitats.

grants.title: Pond management (first 100 sq m)
grants.label: How many ponds?
grants.summary: This item will create networks or complexes of at least 3 ponds and restore the wildlife value of ponds that have become degraded.

grants.title: Pond management (areas more than 100 sq m)
grants.label: What's the size in square meters?
grants.summary: This item will create networks or complexes of at least 3 ponds and restore the wildlife value of ponds that have become degraded.

grants.title: Restoration of large water bodies
grants.label: What is the actual cost?
grants.hint: We will pay up to 100% of actual costs
grants.summary: It will restore the wildlife value of large water bodies that have become degraded.

grants.title: Timber Sluice
grants.label: how many sluices?
grants.summary: It will provide a simple mechanism for water level control, which will support raised water levels for restoring or creating habitats.

grants.title: Brick, stone or concrete sluice
grants.label: how many sluices?
grants.summary: It aims to provide a robust and substantial structure for water level control to support raised water levels for habitat restoration or creation.

grants.title: Buffering in-field ponds and ditches in improved grassland
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Grassland, Uplands, Water quality, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.packages: Pollinators and Wildlife, Improving Water Quality
grants.summary: This option will protect ponds and high value ditches from nutrient leaching and runoff. This will maintain and enhance water quality and wildlife.

grants.title: Management of lowland raised bog
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.packages: Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk, Drought and Wildfire Mitigation
grants.summary:
It will help to manage and restore priority lowland raised bog habitat

If successful there will be:

a rain-fed water table kept close to the surface of the peat
a cover of characteristic bog vegetation such as sphagnum moss and cotton grass maintained or expanded
reduced amounts of invasive bracken, scrub or non-native species

grants.title: Wetland cutting supplement
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It supports the appropriate cutting management of wetland habitats.

grants.title: Wetland grazing supplement
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.summary: It supports the appropriate grazing management of wetland habitats.

grants.title: Buffering in-field ponds and ditches on arable land
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.use: Arable land, Uplands, Water quality, Pollinators and wildlife
grants.packages: Pollinators and Wildlife, Improving Water Quality
grants.summary: This option will protect ponds and high value ditches from nutrient leaching and runoff. This will maintain and enhance water quality and wildlife.

grants.title: Management of ditches of high environmental value
grants.label: What is the length in metres (m)?
grants.hint: We will pay per 100m
grants.packages: Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk, Drought and Wildfire Mitigation
grants.summary: It will manage ditches of high environmental value that support target species of plants, birds, mammals and invertebrates. It will also manage ditches that are essential to carrying out the wet grassland and wetland options.

grants.title: Pond management – first 100 sq m
grants.label: How many ponds?
grants.summary: It will protect and enhance small ponds of high wildlife value.

grants.title: Pond management (areas more than 100 sq m)
grants.label: How many ponds?
grants.summary: It will protect and enhance larger ponds of high wildlife value.

grants.title: Management of reedbed
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.packages: Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk, Drought and Wildfire Mitigation
grants.summary:
It is for managing, maintaining and restoring priority reedbed habitat.

If successful there will be predominantly open, reed-dominated vegetation with occasional scrub, and open water features along ditch lines and ponded areas. High water levels will sustain open water features all year round. Reedbeds will be well maintained or recovering and will support healthy populations of target reedbed species.

grants.title: Creation of reedbed
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.packages: Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk, Drought and Wildfire Mitigation
grants.summary: It will help create new areas of reedbed priority habitat on land that is currently of low wildlife value. If successful it will generate open reed-dominated vegetation on waterlogged ground, interspersed with open water features along ditch lines and pond areas sustained all year round. The reedbed will support healthy populations of target reedbed species.

grants.title: Management of fen
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.packages: Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk, Drought and Wildfire Mitigation
grants.summary:
It will help maintain and restore priority fen habitat and small areas of reedbed.

If successful there will be predominantly open fen vegetation, with occasional scrub. There may also be small open water features along ditch lines, water tracks and ponded areas. High water levels will be sustained by a natural, unpolluted water supply which will support a diverse range of target fen species.

grants.title: Creation of fen
grants.label: What is the size of your land in hectares (ha)?
grants.packages: Flood Mitigation and Coastal Risk, Drought and Wildfire Mitigation
grants.summary:
It will help create new areas of fen priority habitat on land with low wildlife value, particularly around existing wetland habitats.

If successful this option will create predominantly open fen vegetation, with occasional scrub. There may be small open water features along ditch lines, water tracks and ponded areas. High water levels will be sustained by a natural, unpolluted water supply which will support a diverse range of target fen species.
